description: Number of instances of a process(es) currently executing on a host.
interpretation: This value indicates whether too many or too few processes corresponding to an application are executing on the host, which can signal misconfiguration, crashes, or runaway process spawning.
troubleshootingSteps: Define expected minimum and maximum instance counts for key applications (for example, 1 web worker master with N children) and alert when the measure goes outside this range.
If too few instances are running, check whether the process has crashed or been stopped, review application and system logs, and restart services as needed.
If too many instances are running, investigate for runaway scripts, misconfigured services, or orphaned child processes continually being spawned.
Correlate instance count changes with deployment events, configuration changes, or scheduler/cron jobs to identify the source of abnormal process creation.
Use OS tools (such as task manager, top/ps, or process explorers) to verify the list of processes matching the pattern and confirm that they are all legitimate.

description: Percentage of CPU used by executing process(es) corresponding to the pattern specified.
interpretation: A very high value could indicate that processes corresponding to the specified pattern are consuming excessive CPU resources, potentially degrading overall system performance.
troubleshootingSteps: Establish a normal CPU utilization baseline for the process pattern and set thresholds to alert when sustained usage significantly exceeds that baseline.
When CPU is high, inspect per‑process CPU usage with OS tools to identify which specific instance or thread is consuming the most CPU.
Review recent code or configuration changes for the application that might introduce tight loops, inefficient algorithms, or excessive polling.
Check for external load spikes (for example, increased user traffic or batch jobs) and, if needed, scale out or throttle work to reduce CPU pressure.
Capture profiling data or stack traces from high‑CPU processes to locate hot paths and optimize or fix them.

description: For one or more processes corresponding to a specified set of patterns, this value represents the ratio of the resident set size of the processes to the physical memory of the host system, expressed as a percentage.
interpretation: A sudden increase in memory utilization for a process(es) may be indicative of memory leaks in the application or configuration issues that cause excessive caching or buffering.
troubleshootingSteps: Monitor memory utilization trends over time and alert on sustained growth that does not return to baseline after load subsides.
Use system tools to inspect per‑process memory (RSS, private bytes) and identify which instances are growing fastest.
Review application logs and configuration for settings related to caches, queues, and buffers that might be retaining data longer than necessary.
If a memory leak is suspected, reproduce the issue in a test environment with profilers or leak‑detection tools to find unbounded allocations.
When memory growth threatens system stability, consider restarting the affected process during a controlled maintenance window while you work on a permanent fix.
